these terms so continuous integration this is when you as a Ross developer will be continuously merging your code
into a shared branch regularly this is important because as you're building
your code you want to make sure that it's going to work with your colleagues in their code that they're writing so if
I have by continuously integrating this to a shared branch we're preventing some of the downstream integration issues
that can be caused when developers are working in silos continuous delivery
refers to creating ready to deploy artifacts in the case of rocks
application developers this is going to be those bundles that you create and are able to deploy both your simulation
environments as well as your physical robots so creating these ready to deploy artifacts again on a regular basis that
enables you to push those changes out to your customers on some cadence and so
this could be daily weekly that would depend on your business requirements so
finally we have continuous deployment this is when every change that gets
submitted and merged into your integration branch results in a
in an actual deployment so in robotics that could be a test suite maybe you want to test your applications
physically after and change is made that integration branch it could also mean
publishing it to production robots so with continuous deployment this differs
from delivery and that you're regularly pushing out these changes to your to a
set of robots so we're going to talk about how to functionally implement a
continuous integration continuous delivery generis deployment with Ross applications using AWS but before we do
that let's jump into some of the code development and best practices that are out there so one of the structures that
I follow often when I'm building my applications is behavior driven development so the idea of behavior
driven development is formulating user stories and test criteria in collaboration with your broader
non-technical counterparts on your teams the idea here is to bring everybody in
and collaborate so that we're able to better align and achieve our business goals and then directly include these
new business goals in our agile development process and how we're designing our test cases and designing
